block.p: A FIELD GUIDE TO THE INVISIBLE
A FIELD GUIDE TO THE INVISIBLE

''In medieval times . . . everyone knew perfectly well that the air was rife with menacing spirits,'' the science journalist Wayne Biddle writes in ''A Field Guide to the Invisible.'' But just as ''the souls of unbaptized babies, undead ghouls wandering forever between heaven and hell'' and ''assorted incubi and succubi'' were the bane of our ancestors' existence, so today's unseen bugaboos -- hazardous radiation, pollutants, global warming and deadly viruses -- render ''much of what is invisible to us sophisticated moderns . . . as scary as the enmity of old fiends.'' This mini-encyclopedia of the imperceptible -- an unseen smorgasbord of bacteria and burps, quarks and cooties -- offers a well-researched yet enjoyably irreverent look at the ''parallel world'' that ''we inhabit simultaneously with the one before our very eyes.'' ''A Field Guide to the Invisible'' also reveals how the essential dynamics underlying scientific inquiry can bear an uncanny resemblance to the tenets of religious faith. Thus, gravity ''is the one force in nature that cannot be . . . messed with, the Wonderbra notwithstanding. It is omnipotent and omnipresent, just like You-Know-Who.''
